column1: [ The zebrafish , Danio rerio , is a tropical freshwater fish belonging to the minnow family ( Cyprinidae ) of order Cypriniformes . [ 1 ] It is a popular aquarium fish , frequently sold under the trade name zebra danio , and is an important vertebrate model organism in scientific research. , The zebrafish are Cyprinidae with a derived member of the genus Danio . It has a sister group relationship with Danio kyathit . [ 2 ] , Zebrafish are closely related to the genus Devario , as demonstrated by a phylogenetic tree of close species. Figure 2. Phylogenetic relationships among danios " . http://www.nature.com/hdy/journal/v97/n3/fig_tab/6800867f2.html#figure-title .
column2: The zebrafish is native to the streams of the southeastern Himalayan region
column7: and Myanmar . [ 3 ] It arose in the Ganges region in Eastern India . It commonly inhabits streams
column11: and slow-moving to stagnant water bodies
column13: Zebrafish have been introduced to parts of the United States
column14: presumably by deliberate release or by escape from fish farms. [ 3 ] They have also been sighted in Colombia .
column15: The fish is named for the five uniform
column17: horizontal blue stripes on the side of the body
column18: all of which extend to the end of the caudal fin . Its shape is fusiform and laterally compressed
column19: with its mouth directed upwards. Males are torpedo -shaped and have gold stripes between the blue stripes; females have a larger
column20: whitish belly and have silver stripes instead of gold. Adult females will exhibit a small genital papilla in front of the anal fin origin. The zebrafish can grow to 6.4 centimetres (2.5 in)
column21: although it is uncommon for them to grow past 4 cm in captivity. Life-span in captivity is around 2–3 years
column24: The approximate generation time for the Danio is 3–4 months. A male must be present for ovulation and spawning to occur. Females are able to spawn at intervals of 2–3 days
column25: laying hundreds of eggs in each clutch . Upon release
column27: growth stops after the first few cell divisions. Fertilized eggs almost immediately become transparent
column28: a characteristic that makes D. rerio a convenient research model species . [ 4 ] Development progresses rapidly. Precursors to all major organs appear within 36 hours of fertilization . Hatching takes place 48–72 hours after fertilization
column29: depending on the embryo's internal conditions and the external temperature
column30: ideally 28.5 °C (83.3 °F) . Swimming and feeding behavior begin about 36 hours later. The sex of juveniles cannot be distinguished except by dissection
column31: and sex determinants are not clearly understood.
column32: The zebrafish is omnivorous . It primarily eats zooplankton
column34: and phytoplankton . It can eat a variety of other foods
column35: such as worms and small crustaceans if its preferred sources are not readily available. [ 4 ] Most Danios accept common food flakes and tubifex worms in the aquarium .
column37: transgenic zebrafish have become commercially available that express green fluorescent protein
column39: and yellow fluorescent protein . They are tradenamed GloFish . Other cultivated varieties include golden
column44: is a spotted colour morph of the zebrafish caused by a pigment mutation. [ 5 ]  Xanthistic forms of both the zebra and leopard pattern
column46: have been obtained via selective breeding programs for the aquarium trade. [ 6 ]

column5: Zebrafish are hardy fish and considered good for beginner aquarists . Their ease of keeping and breeding
column8: playful nature and broad availability all contribute to their popularity. They thrive best in 22–28 °C (72–82 °F) water. They need an aquarium of 10 US gallons (38 L) or more
column9: and they do well in schools. They also thrive as shoals of six or more
column10: and interact well with other fish types in the aquarium. However
column11: they are susceptible to Oodinium or velvet disease
column13: and Mycobacterium species. Given the opportunity
column15: which may be protected by separating the two groups with a net
column17: D. rerio is a common and useful model organism for studies of vertebrate development and gene function. [ 2 ]  George Streisinger at the University of Oregon established its utility. Success with it in large scale forward genetic screens (commonly referred to as the Tübingen/Boston screens) consolidated its importance. The scholarly journal Development [ 9 ] devoted an issue [ 10 ] to research using it in celebration of this landmark. It has a dedicated online database of genetic
column20: the Zebrafish Information Network (ZFIN). D. rerio is one of the few fish species to have reached space . They may supplement higher vertebrate models
column22: Research with D. rerio has allowed advances in the fields of developmental biology
column32: Its greatest advantages for use as a model system include:
column34: Zebrafish have the ability to regenerate fins
column36: the heart [ 17 ] and the brain (in larval stages). Heart muscle regeneration does not make use of stem cells ; instead
column37: mature heart muscle cells regress to a stem-cell-like state and redifferentiate. [ 17 ] In 2011 the British Heart Foundation ran an advertising (including on television and online) campaign publicising their intention to study the applicability of this ability to humans by "spend[ing] £50 million on a programme of groundbreaking research that could help us begin to repair damaged [human] hearts." [ 18 ]
column38: Zebrafish have also been found to regenerate photoreceptor cells and retinal neurons following injury. The mechanisms of this regeneration are unknown. Researchers frequently amputate the dorsal and ventral tail fins and analyze their regrowth to test for mutations. This research is leading the scientific community in the understanding of healing/repair mechanisms in vertebrates. It has also been found if the same fin is damaged enough times
column39: the fish will grow a new fin which will have mutated only a small amount. Most scientists believe this is a defence mechanism to try to prevent the fin from being damaged again. [ citation needed ]
column40: A common reverse genetics technique is to reduce gene expression or modify splicing using Morpholino antisense technology. Morpholino oligonucleotides (MO) are stable
column41: synthetic macromolecules that contain the same bases as DNA or RNA; by binding to complementary RNA sequences
column42: they reduce the expression of specific genes. The journal Genesis [ 19 ] devoted an issue [ 20 ] to research using MO
column43: mostly in D. rerio . MO can be injected into one cell of an embryo after the 32-cell stage
column44: reducing gene expression in only cells descended from that cell. However
column45: cells in the early embryo (less than 32 cells) are interpermeable to large molecules
column46: [ 21 ]  [ 22 ] allowing diffusion between cells. A known problem with gene knockdowns is that
column47: because the genome underwent a duplication after the divergence of ray-finned fishes and lobe-finned fishes
column48: it is not always easy to silence the activity one of the two gene paralogs reliably due to complementation by the other paralog.
column49: Despite the complications of the zebrafish genome
column50: a number of commercially available global platforms for analysis of both gene expression by microarrays and promoter regulation using ChIP-on-chip exist.

column53: Delhi announced the sequencing of a wild caught strain
column56: researchers from the University of Oklahoma published D. rerio's complete mitochondrial DNA sequence. [ 25 ] Its length is 16
column57: 596 base pairs. This is within 100 base pairs of other related species of fish
column58: and it is notably only 18 pairs longer than the goldfish ( Carassius auratus ) and 21 longer than the carp ( Cyprinus carpio ). Its gene order and content is identical to the common vertebrate form of mitochondrial DNA. It contains 13 protein -coding genes and a noncoding control region containing the origin of replication for the heavy strand. In between a grouping of five tRNA genes
column59: a sequence resembling vertebrate origin of light strand replication is found. It is difficult to draw evolutionary conclusions because it is difficult to determine whether base pair changes have adaptive significance via comparisons with other vertebrates nucleotide sequences.
column61: a study of the golden strain identified the gene responsible for its unusual pigmentation as SLC24A5
column62: a solute carrier that appeared to be required for melanin production
column63: and confirmed its function with a Morpholino knockdown. The orthologous gene was then characterized in humans and a one base pair difference was found to strongly segregate fair-skinned Europeans and dark-skinned Africans. [ 26 ]
column64: Transgenesis is a popular approach to study the function of genes in zebrafish. Construction of transgenic zebrafish is rather easy by a method using the Tol2 transposon system. [ 27 ]
column66: Chinese researchers at Fudan University genetically modified fish to detect oestrogen pollution in lakes and rivers
column67: which is linked to male infertility. [ 28 ]
column68: In cardiovascular research the zebrafish is being used to model blood clotting
column71: and congenital heart disease . In programmes of research into acute inflammation
column72: a major underpinning process in many diseases
column73: researchers have established a zebrafish model of inflammation
column74: and its resolution. An approach that allows detailed study of the genetic controls of inflammation and the possibility of identifying potential new drugs.
column75: Another focus of work is to understand how a gene called Hedgehog
column76: a biological signal that underlies a number of human cancers
column77: controls cell growth. This is fast becoming an avenue of research that is leading to new cancer therapies. In probing disorders of the nervous system
column81: researchers are using the zebrafish to understand how the genetic defects underlying these conditions cause functional abnormalities in the human brain
column82: spinal cord and sensory organs. Researchers are delving into the complexities of muscle degeneration in genetic models of human musculoskeletal diseases
column84: These studies exemplify how zebrafish research offers unique opportunities to understanding some of the greatest challenges in medical science
column85: by enabling new discoveries of how cells and tissues work to be translated into new ways of understanding a broad range of human diseases.
column87: and as demonstrated through ongoing research programmes
column88: the zebrafish models affords an ideal opportunity
column89: not only to identify novel candidates for genes underlying human disease
column90: but offers a potential system in which to begin to develop novel therapeutic agents in drug discovery programmes
column91: hence helping to identify new treatments. [ 29 ]
column93: researchers at University College London grew a type of zebrafish adult stem cell found in the eyes of fish and mammals that develops into neurons in the retina —the part of the eye that sends messages to the brain. These cells could be injected in the eye to treat diseases that damage retinal neurons—nearly every disease of the eye
column96: and diabetes -related blindness . Retinal damage is responsible for most cases of sight loss. The researchers studied Müller glial cells in the eyes of humans aged from 18 months to 91 years and were able to develop them into all types of retinal neurons. They were able to grow them easily in the lab. The stem cells successfully migrated into diseased rats' retinas and took on the characteristics of the surrounding neurons. The team is working on the same approach in humans. [ 30 ]
column98: researchers at Children's Hospital Boston developed a new strain of zebrafish
column100: whose adult bodies were transparent. [ 31 ] This allows for detailed visualization of cellular activity
column102: metastasis and many other phenomena. Because many gene functions are shared between fish and humans
column103: Casper is expected to yield insight into human diseases such as leukemia and other cancers. [ 31 ]  [ 32 ] ]";"876";"disease
